choices.text: Stage of displacement > stage of degeneration > stage of sequestration > stage of extrusion
Stage of degeneration > stage of sequestration > stage of displacement > stage of extrusion
Stage of degeneration > stage of displacement > stage of extrusion > stage of sequestration
Stage of extrusion > Stage of degeneration > stage of sequestration > stage of displacement

questions.text: A 40 yr old gym trainer with a frequent history of heavy weight lifting complains of chronic lower back pain and recently the pain has started radiating to the left lower limb. MRI shows L4-L5 disc prolapse. Correct sequence of progression of intervertebral disc prolapse is:
questions.solution:
Intervertebral Disc Prolapse

a) Nucleus Degeneration

  • Definition: The initial phase of disc degeneration before any displacement of the nucleus occurs.
  • Characteristics:
    • Softening of the Nucleus: The nucleus pulposus (the gel-like center of the disc) becomes softer and more pliable.
    • Fragmentation: The nucleus begins to fragment or break down into smaller pieces.
    • Weakening of Annulus: The annulus fibrosus (the tough outer ring of the disc) weakens, particularly the posterior part, leading to disintegration.

b) Nucleus Displacement

  • Definition: The movement or bulging of the nucleus pulposus due to internal pressure and structural weaknesses in the disc.
  • Characteristics:
    • Disc Protrusion: The nucleus bulges through a weakened area of the annulus fibrosus. This is often due to the degeneration of the annulus, which may occur spontaneously or due to trauma.
    • Disc Extrusion: As the disc continues to degenerate and the annulus becomes more compromised, the nucleus can push out of the annulus and lie beneath the posterior longitudinal ligament. At this stage, it may still remain attached to the parent disc.

c) Stage of Extrusion

  • Definition: A specific phase where the nucleus pulposus has moved beyond the confines of the annulus fibrosus.
  • Characteristics:
    • Extruded Nucleus: The nucleus exits through the annulus and is located under the posterior longitudinal ligament.
    • Irreversibility: Once the nucleus is extruded, it does not naturally return to its original position. The posterior longitudinal ligament alone is usually insufficient to prevent further displacement.

d) Stage of Sequestration

  • Definition: The final stage where the extruded disc material becomes a separate fragment from the main disc.
  • Characteristics:
    • Sequestrated Disc: The extruded nucleus may lose its connection with the parent disc and become a free fragment within the spinal canal.
    • Location: This fragment can end up lying behind the posterior longitudinal ligament or elsewhere in the spinal canal.

Key takeaway:

Correct order of progression of pathology in IVDP is:- Stage of degeneration > stage of displacement > stage of extrusion > stage of sequestration

questions.text: Most common level to undergo IVDP is?
questions.solution:
The commonest level of disc prolapse is between L4-L5 in the lumbar spine and C5-C6 in the cervical spine. In the lumbar spine, it is uncommon above L3-L4 level. (Option B)

Clinical Features

  • Patient Profile: Usually an adult between 20-40 years of age with a sedentary lifestyle.
  • Common Symptoms:
    • Low Back Pain:
      • Acute Backache:
        • Severe, with spine held rigid by muscle spasm.
        • Painful movement; patient may be incapacitated.
      • Chronic Backache:
        • Dull, diffuse pain worsened by exertion, forward bending, sitting, or standing for long periods.
        • Relieved by rest.
  • Sciatic Pain:
    • Often associated with low back pain, but may be the sole symptom.
    • Pain radiates to:
      • Gluteal region
      • Back of the thigh and leg
    • Radiation Patterns:
      • S1 Root Compression: Pain radiates to the postero-lateral calf and heel.
      • L5 Root Compression: Pain radiates to the anterolateral aspect of the leg and ankle.
      • Higher Disc Prolapse (L2-L3 etc.): Pain may radiate to the front of the thigh.
    • Pain often begins with walking and is relieved by rest (neurological claudication).
  • Neurological Symptoms:
    • Paraesthesias: 'Pins and needles' sensation corresponding to the dermatome of the affected nerve root.
    • Numbness and Weakness:
      • Numbness in the leg or foot.
      • Muscle weakness.
    • Cauda Equina Syndrome (if large disc material compresses the theca and roots):
      • Irregular LMN type paralysis in lower limbs.
      • Bilateral absent ankle jerks.
      • Hypoaesthesia in L5 to S4 dermatomes.
      • Urinary and bowel incontinence.

Key takeaways:

  • Overall most common is IVDP at the lumbar spine at L4-L5 level.
  • Investigation of choice is MRI.
  • Most common symptom is lower back pain.

choices.text: MRI to be done for cauda equina syndrome
MRI to be done acute for disc prolapse
Xray to be done for burst fracture of vertebrae

questions.text: A 34 yr old body-builder presents with complaints of severe pain in lower back radiating to the whole left lower limb, anaesthesia over left buttock, weakness in legs and loss of bladder control for the last 2 days after the history of weight lifting. Choose the correct option.
questions.solution:
The history and findings fits perfect for Cauda equina syndrome

Cauda Equina Syndrome

  • Causes:
    • Large extruded disc
    • Surgical trauma
    • Hematoma
  • Symptoms:
    • Bilateral buttock and lower extremity pain
    • Bowel or bladder dysfunction (usually urinary retention)
    • Saddle anesthesia
    • Varying degrees of lower extremity motor or sensory dysfunction
  • Initial Diagnosis:
    • Digital rectal examination:
      • Assess rectal tone
      • Evaluate perianal sensation
      • Check for volitional control and contraction
      • Perianal sensation evaluation is crucial for immediate diagnosis
    • Imaging:
      • Urgent/emergent MRI: (Option A)
        • Helps assess cauda equina compression
      • Surgical Decompression:
        • Timing:
          • Controversial, but earliest possible decompression is generally indicated to prevent progression of neurologic loss
        • Best Outcomes:
          • Surgical decompression within the first 48 hours has been associated with the best recovery outcomes, although prognosis remains guarded in most cases

Option B - Acute disc prolapse won't cause so much neurological involvement suddenly.

Option C - There is no history of trauma to cause burst fracture of vertebrae

Option D - As bowel and bladder are involved, urgent steps have to be taken to find the cause. Observation alone doesn't suffice.

Key takeaways

Cauda Equina Syndrome - Mnemonic - "SADDLE BAGS"

  • Saddle anesthesia
  • Abdominal or lower extremity pain
  • Dysfunction in bowel or bladder (urinary retention)
  • Digital rectal examination (for initial diagnosis)
  • Loss of motor or sensory function in lower extremities
  • Emergent MRI (for assessing compression)
  • Best outcomes with decompression within 48 hours
  • Assessment of perianal sensation
  • Guarded prognosis if not treated early
  • Surgical decompression is key

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient with a family history of ankylosing spondylitis presents with neck pain and stiffness. Her investigations are likely to show all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Radiology of Ankylosing Spondylitis

  1. Lumbar Spine X-Ray Findings:
  • Squaring of Vertebrae:
    • Vertebrae become squared off due to loss of normal curvature and disc space narrowing.
  • Loss of Lumbar Lordosis:
    • Normal curvature of the lumbar spine is lost, resulting in a more straightened appearance.
  • Bridging Osteophytes (Syndesmophytes):
    • Bony outgrowths form at the anterior aspects of the vertebrae, bridging adjacent vertebrae.
  • Bamboo Spine Appearance: (Option B)
    • The spine takes on a characteristic appearance due to the formation of syndesmophytes and calcification of the anterior longitudinal ligament, resembling bamboo.
  1. Pelvis X-Ray Findings:
  • Haziness of the Sacroiliac Joints:
    • Irregular subchondral erosion and loss of joint definition.
  • Sclerosis and Widening of SI Joints:
    • Increased bone density (sclerosis) and widening of the articulating surfaces.
  • Bony Ankylosis of the Sacroiliac Joints: (Option C)
    • Fusion of the sacroiliac joints, resulting in loss of joint mobility.
  • Calcification of Ligaments:
    • Calcification of the sacroiliac ligament and sacro-tuberous ligaments.
  • Evidence of Enthesopathy:
    • Calcification at the attachment sites of muscles, tendons, and ligaments, particularly around the pelvis and heel.
  1. Peripheral Joints X-Ray Findings:
  • Similar to Rheumatoid Arthritis:
    • X-ray changes can resemble those seen in rheumatoid arthritis, including joint space narrowing and erosions.
  • Formation of Large Osteophytes:
    • Development of large bony outgrowths at the joint margins.
  • Periarticular Calcification:
    • Calcification around the joints, which is less common in rheumatoid arthritis.

Option A, B & C: Positive for HLA B27, Bamboo spine appearance & Bony ankylosis for SI joints all 3 are features of Ankylosing spondylitis.

Key takeaways:

Ankylosing spondylitis:

  • HLA B27 Positivity
  • Bamboo spine Appearance
  • Bony ankylosis of SI Joint
  • Periarticular calcification in peripheral joints,

choices.text: Fracture through the pedicle and lamina of C3 vertebra, with subluxation of C2 over C3
Fracture through the body of C2 vertebra, with subluxation of C2 over C3
Fracture through the pedicle and lamina of C2 vertebra, with subluxation of C2 over C3

questions.text: Hangman's fracture: Choose the correct answer.
questions.solution:
1. C2 Fracture (Traumatic Spondylolisthesis of the Axis, or Hangman's Fracture)
  2. Treatment:
  • Type I:
    • Rigid cervical orthosis.
  • Type II:
    • Operative; typically C1-2 fixation or direct osteosynthesis.
  • Type IIA:
    • Halo vest or surgery (no traction).
  • Type III:
    • Generally operative, usually C2-3 fusion.
    • May require C1-3 fixation depending on comminution of pars and quality of fixation into C2.
  1. Complications:
  • Vascular Injury:
    • Vertebral artery injury is rare but increasingly diagnosed by MR angiogram.
  • Neurologic Injury:
    • Potential injury to C2 (greater occipital) nerve causing numbness in the posterior skull.
  • Dural Leaks:
  • Nonunion/Malunion:
  1. C1-2 Posterior Cervical Fixation Techniques:
  • C1-2 Modified Gallie Fusion:
    • Autograft iliac crest placed over C2 spinous process and against posterior arch of C1.
    • Held in place by a single sublaminar wire.
  • C1-2 Brooks Fusion:
    • Two separate iliac crest autografts placed between C1 and C2.
    • Two sublaminar wires, one on either side.
  • C1-2 Transarticular (Magerl) Screws:
    • Preoperative CT scan to assess vertebral artery location at C1-2 junction.
    • Screw placed through C1-2 facet joint under fluoroscopic guidance.
  • C1 Lateral Mass-C2 Pedicle (Harms) Screws:
    • C1 screws placed through the lateral masses; starting point at the center of the lateral mass.
    • C2 screws placed as pedicle screws or, if vertebral artery is aberrant, a shorter, straight-ahead pars screw.
  1. Complications of Fixation Techniques:
  • Vertebral Artery Injury:
    • Injury may occur as the artery runs in the transverse foramen of C2 or lies on the superior aspect of C1.
  • C2 Nerve Injury:
    • Injury to the C2 nerve may cause numbness in the posterior skull.

Options A, B, and D:

Type III fractures are usually called Hangman's fracture with fracture through the pedicle and lamina of C2 vertebra, with subluxation of C2 over C3

Key takeaways:

choices.text: Ecchymosis can be seen in the abdominal region
Mechanism of injury is flexion-distraction force
Occurs at the level of the cervicothoracic spine

questions.text: Chance fracture: Choose the false option.
questions.solution:
Chance Fractures (Seat Belt Fractures)

Definition:

  • Chance Fracture: Also known as a seat belt fracture (Option A), this injury involves a horizontal fracture line that traverses the body of the vertebra and extends through to the posterior elements. It typically results from a flexion-distraction mechanism.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Seat Belt Sign: One of the key physical exam findings is ecchymosis (bruising) (Option B) on the abdominal wall in the region where the seat belt would be worn. This sign is indicative of the trauma that led to the fracture.
  • Associated Risk: The presence of a seat belt sign can be associated with an increased risk of small bowel perforation, with a reported risk increase of approximately 5%.

Mechanism:

  • Flexion-Distraction Injury (Option C): Chance fractures are a type of flexion-distraction injury affecting the thoracolumbar spine (Option D). The injury is caused by a force that is transmitted posteriorly along an anterior-posterior plane, often related to high-energy impacts such as motor vehicle accidents where seat belts are involved.

Option A, B & C: Chance Fracture Also called seat belt fracture causes Ecchymosis in the abdominal region. Mechanism of injury is the flexion-distraction force.

Option D: Occurs at the level of the cervicothoracic spine is false. It's mc at thoracolumbar spine.

Key takeaways:

Chance Fractures / Seat belt fractures:

  • Due to Flexion distraction injury
  • Seat belt sign - Ecchymosis over anterior abdomen
  • MC at Thoracolumbar spine

questions.text: An 55 yr old man with chronic lower back pain radiating to both lower limbs consulted an orthopedic surgeon. Xray LS spine lateral which looked as shown. Diagnose the condition.
questions.solution:
Spondylolisthesis: Pathology & Types

Normal Vertebral Stability:

  • Forward displacement of a vertebral body is prevented by:
    • Articular processes of adjacent vertebrae
    • Intervertebral disc and ligamentous attachments (to a lesser extent)
  • Spondylolisthesis: A condition where a vertebra slips forward over the one below due to a defect in this "check" mechanism.

Types of Spondylolisthesis:

  1. Isthmic Spondylolisthesis (most common type):
    • Involves a lesion in the pars interarticularis.
    • Subtypes:
      • Lytic: Due to a fatigue fracture of the pars interarticularis.
      • Elongated: The pars interarticularis remains intact but is abnormally elongated.
      • Acute fracture: A fracture of the pars interarticularis causing separation.
    • Pathomechanics:
      • The anterior half of the vertebra (including the vertebral body, pedicles, and superior articular facets) slips forward along with the spinal column above it.
      • The posterior half (laminae and inferior articular facets) stays aligned with the vertebra below.
  2. Dysplastic Spondylolisthesis:
    • Least common type.
    • Results from a congenital abnormality in vertebral development, leading to vertebral slippage.
  3. Degenerative Spondylolisthesis:
    • Common in elderly individuals.
    • Caused by osteoarthritis of the posterior facet joints, leading to instability and subluxation.
    • Retrolisthesis (backward displacement) may occur in some cases.
    • Displacement is usually minor, with rare neurological involvement.
  4. Pathological Spondylolisthesis:
    • Results from generalized or localized bone disease that weakens vertebral articulation.
  5. Traumatic Spondylolisthesis:
    • Rare type.
    • Occurs when one vertebra slips over another following trauma or injury

WHY NOT OTHERS

  • Option A - Spondylosis is Degenerative spine disease commonly seen in old age.
  • Option B - Spondylitis is Inflammatory condition involving the spine at a younger age. e.g. ankylosing spondylitis
  • Option C - Spondylolisthesis is forward displacement of a vertebra over the one below it. It commonly occurs between L5-S1, and between L4-L5. Occasionally, the displacement is backwards (retrolisthesis) Hence Correct Option.

Key takeaways:

Spondylolisthesis is forward displacement of a vertebra over the one below it. It commonly occurs between L5-S1, and between L4-L5. Occasionally, the displacement is backwards (retrolisthesis).

questions.text: Beheaded Scottish dog sign which is diagnostic of spondylolisthesis is seen in which view of xray?
questions.solution:
Oblique view Helps visualize the pars interarticularis thus giving beheaded Scottish Appearance in spondylolisthesis.

Diagnosis of Spondylolisthesis

Physical Examination:

  • Visible or palpable 'step' deformity above the sacral crest due to forward displacement of the spinal column.
  • Increased lumbar lordosis may be noted.
  • Sciatic nerve stretch signs, such as a positive straight leg raising test (SLRT), may indicate nerve involvement.

Radiological Examination:

  • X-ray Findings:
    • Lateral view of the spine shows anterior displacement of one vertebra over the other. (Option B)
    • Grading of spondylolisthesis based on severity of vertebral slip:
      • Grade I: Displacement up to 25% of the antero-posterior width of the lower vertebral body.
      • Grade II: Displacement of 26-50%.
      • Grade III: Displacement of 51-75%.
      • Grade IV: Complete forward displacement (100%).
    • Oblique view: (Option C)
      • Helps visualize the pars interarticularis.
      • In a normal vertebra, the pars interarticularis resembles a "Scottish dog".
      • Spondylolysis (defect without vertebral slip):
        • Appears as a "Scottish dog wearing a collar", indicating a defect in the isthmus (pars interarticularis).
      • Spondylolisthesis (defect with vertebral slip):
        • Appears as the "head of the Scottish dog separated from the neck", indicating a defect with slippage of the vertebra.

Option A: X Ray AP view is not of much use in diagnosing spondylolisthesis.

Option B: Lateral view of the spine shows anterior displacement of one vertebra over the other and thus helps in Grading spondylolisthesis.

Option C: Oblique view Helps visualize the pars interarticularis thus giving beheaded Scottish Appearance in spondylolisthesis.

Key takeaways

Interpretation of Lumbosacral Spine Oblique X Ray view:

  1. Normal Vertebra:
    • The pars interarticularis appears as a well-formed "Scottish dog" with no abnormalities.
  2. Spondylolysis (defect without vertebral slip):
    • The "Scottish dog" appears to be "wearing a collar".
    • This indicates a defect in the isthmus (pars interarticularis), but no vertebral displacement.
  3. Spondylolisthesis (defect with vertebral slip):
    • The head of the "Scottish dog" appears separated from the neck.
    • This indicates a defect with slippage of the vertebra.

choices.text: Upper motor neuron type of paralysis is not seen

questions.text: Central cord syndrome: All of these are true except -
questions.solution:
Types of Incomplete Lesions:

  1. Central Cord Lesion:
    • Commonest type of incomplete lesion. (Option A)
    • Characterized by:
      • Initial flaccid weakness.
      • Lower motor neuron paralysis of the upper limbs.
      • Upper motor neuron (spastic) paralysis of the lower limbs. (Option D)
      • Bladder control and perianal sensations are usually preserved (sacral sparing). (Option B and C)
  2. Anterior Cord Lesion:
    • Results in:
      • Complete paralysis and anaesthesia.
      • Deep pressure and position sense (proprioception) are retained in the lower limbs (due to dorsal column sparing).
  3. Posterior Cord Lesion:
    • Very rare type of lesion.
    • Results in loss of:
      • Deep pressure
      • Proprioception (position sense).
  4. Cord Hemi-section (Brown-Séquard Syndrome):
    • Characterized by:
      • Ipsilateral paralysis (on the same side as the lesion).
      • Contralateral loss of pain sensation (on the opposite side of the lesion).

Option A, B & C: Central cord lesion are incomplete sparing sacrum and bowel bladder.

Option D: Upper motor neuron type of paralysis is not seen as a false Statement. Because Lower limb shows UMN Palsy.

Key takeaways:

Central Cord Lesion (Commonest Incomplete Lesion)

  • Sparing:
    • Bladder control is preserved.
    • Perianal sensations are intact (sacral sparing).

questions.text: All of the following are clinical tests used in Marie Strumpell disease to look for SI joint involvement except:
questions.solution:
- Lasegue test is used for examination of PIVD/ nerve root compression/ Sciatica

Ankylosing Spondylitis (Marie Strumpell Disease)

Overview:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the spine and sacroiliac (SI) joints.
  • The SI joint is usually the first and most common joint to be involved.

Examination of SI Joint Involvement:

  1. Sacro-iliac Compression Test: (Option B)
    • Technique: Direct side-to-side compression of the pelvis.
    • Positive sign: Pain at the sacro-iliac joints, indicating SI joint involvement.
  2. Gaenslen's Test: (Option A)
    • Technique:
      • The opposite hip and knee are flexed to stabilize the pelvis.
      • The hip joint of the side under examination is hyperextended over the edge of the table.
    • Positive sign: Rotational strain on the SI joint causes pain.
  3. Pump-handle Test: (Option C)
    • Technique:
      • With the patient supine, the examiner fully flexes the hip and knee on the affected side.
      • The affected knee is then brought across the chest towards the opposite shoulder.
    • Positive sign: Pain on the affected side, indicating SI joint involvement.

Option A, B & C:

Option D - Lasegue test is used for examination of PIVD/ nerve root compression/ Sciatica.

Key takeaways

  • HLA-B27 is positive in most cases of AS
  • X Rays spine lateral view shows typical Bamboo spine appearance.

questions.text: A home-maker had sustained injury over wrist joint while cutting vegetables which was sutured at a local clinic in the village. After 3 months she started to get an MRI done which showed ulnar nerve injury. Which of the following tests will not be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Clinical Presentation: Based on the history and observed deformity, the patient exhibits signs of an ulnar claw hand. This condition is characterized by the clawing of the medial two fingers, which is commonly associated with an ulnar nerve injury.

Mnemonic for Ulnar Nerve Examination: BCDEF of Music

  • B - Book Test (Option B): A diagnostic test to assess ulnar nerve function.
  • C - Card Test (Option A): Another test used to evaluate the integrity of interossei muscles.
  • D - ADductor Pollicis Paralysis: Assessing for paralysis of the adductor pollicis muscle, which is innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • E - Egawa Test (Option D): A specific test for ulnar nerve function.
  • F - Froment's Sign: A clinical sign indicating ulnar nerve dysfunction, typically observed during pinching tasks.
  • Music - Musician's Nerve: A mnemonic reference indicating the ulnar nerve's significance, often referred to as the 'musician's nerve' due to its crucial role in hand function.

Book test (Froment sign)

(Option C) - Pen test is for median nerve examination.

Pen test

Key takeaways:

Mnemonic for ulnar nerve - BCDEF of Music

B- Book test

C- Card test

D- ADductor pollicis paralysis

E- Egawa test

F- Froment's sign

Music - Musician's nerve

questions.text: Match the following according to Seddon's classification for nerve injuries:
questions.solution:
Seddon's Classification of Nerve Injury

  1. Neuropraxia
    • Definition: The mildest form of nerve injury.
    • Characteristics:
      • Function: Temporary loss of nerve function.
      • Cause: Compression or stretching of the nerve.
      • Recovery: Complete recovery usually occurs within a few days to weeks.
      • Histological Findings: No significant axonal damage; myelin sheath may be affected.
  2. Axonotmesis
    • Definition: Moderate nerve injury.
    • Characteristics:
      • Function: Disruption of the axon with preservation of the nerve sheath.
      • Cause: More severe compression or stretching, causing axonal damage.
      • Recovery: Recovery is generally good with proper intervention, usually occurring over several months.
      • Histological Findings: Damage to the axon with degeneration of distal nerve fibers; the endoneurium remains intact.
  3. Neurotmesis
    • Definition: Severe nerve injury.
    • Characteristics:
      • Function: Complete severance of the nerve, including both the axon and the connective tissue structures.
      • Cause: Severe trauma such as lacerations or avulsions.
      • Recovery: Recovery is poor without surgical intervention, and even with surgery, functional recovery may be incomplete.
      • Histological Findings: Complete disruption of the nerve, including axon, myelin, and connective tissue structures (epineurium, perineurium, and endoneurium).

This classification helps in determining the appropriate management and predicting the potential for recovery based on the extent of never injury.

Key takeaways:

  • According to Seddon's classification, neuroma in continuity is classified in axonotmesis.
  • According to Sunderland's classification, neuroma in continuity is classified as a 4th degree injury.

questions.text: Another name of reflex sympathetic dystrophy in modern orthopaedics is:
questions.solution:
Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS)

  1. Definition and General Features:
    • Abnormal and Excessive Limb Pain: CRPS is characterized by intense and disproportionate pain in a limb.
    • Changes in the Limb: The affected limb shows various changes, including early signs of inflammation.
    • Early Features of Inflammation:
      • Swelling: The limb often becomes swollen.
      • Vasomotor Dysfunction: Abnormalities in blood vessel regulation, leading to changes in skin color and temperature.
      • Sudomotor Dysfunction: Altered sweating patterns in the affected limb.
    • Progression: Over time, inflammation may recede but lead to persistent issues such as:
      • Contracture: Stiffening and shortening of muscles or tendons.
      • Osteoporosis: Thinning of the bone in the affected area.
  2. Types of CRPS
    • CRPS1
      • Former Name: Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy (RSD). (Option A)
      • Characteristics: No demonstrable nerve damage is observed.
      • Prevalence: More common compared to CRPS2.
      • Prognosis: Generally guarded; recovery can be variable.
    • CRPS2 (Option B)
      • Former Name: Causalgia. (Option D)
      • Characteristics: Identifiable nerve damage is present.
      • Prognosis: Typically very poor, with a less favorable outcome.
  3. Sudek's Osteodystrophy (Option C)
    • Feature of CRPS: This condition is associated with CRPS.
    • Characteristics: Osteoporosis in the bones of the affected region, contributing to bone weakening and increased fracture risk.

Key takeaways:

  • Former name of CRPS 2 is causalgia
  • Former name of CRPS 1 is RSD

choices.text: 1st MCP joint arthritis due to bowling

questions.text: A bowling champion presents with complaints of pain and difficult grasping from the dominant thumb. X Ray is normal but clinically it is diagnosed as bowler's thumb. Select true statement about the same:
questions.solution:
Bowler's Thumb

  1. Definition and Cause
    • Condition: Perineural fibrosis of the ulnar digital nerve of the thumb.
    • Cause: Repetitive compression of the nerve while grasping a bowling ball.
    • Affected Individuals: Typically bowlers who participate several times a week.
  2. Symptoms
    • Tingling and Hyperesthesia: Sensations of tingling and increased sensitivity around the pulp of the thumb.
    • Palpable Lump: A tender lump may be felt in the affected area.
    • Distal Skin Atrophy: Atrophy or thinning of the skin in the distal region of the thumb may occur.
  3. Management and Prevention
    • Early Awareness: Recognizing the condition early can help prevent worsening.
    • Protective Measures:
      • Shield or Splint: Using a shield or splint can protect the thumb from further compression.
      • Rest from Bowling: Taking a break from bowling allows the affected area to heal and reduces symptoms.
  4. Treatment Options
    • Neurolysis: In some cases, surgical intervention to release the nerve may be necessary.
    • Dorsal Transfer of the Nerve: This procedure may be considered to relieve compression and improve function if conservative measures are not effective.

Option A - 1st CMC is the second most common joint to undergo OA after the knee joint. But not seen in bowler's thumb.

Option B - Bowler's thumb refers to neuropathy of ulnar digital nerve of thumb

Option C - Gamekeeper's thumb refers to tear of ulnar collateral ligament at the 1st MCP joint.

Option D - EPL tenosynovitis is usually seen in cases of rheumatoid arthritis.

Key takeaways:

Bowlers thumb:

  • Perineural fibrosis of the ulnar digital nerve of the thumb due to repetitive movements.
  • Present with Tingling, Hyperesthesia and distal atrophy of skin.
  • Managed with Splint & Neurolysis if Required.

choices.text: Dorsal scapular nerve is involved in C5 root lesion
Positive triple response after histamine injection is seen in pre ganglionic lesion
Normal SNAPs but loss of sensation on examination indicates postganglionic injury
Pseudomeningocele formation on MRI is characteristic of preganglionic lesions

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding brachial plexus injury except:
questions.solution:
1. Importance of Anatomy:
    • Knowledge of brachial plexus anatomy is essential for evaluating and diagnosing brachial plexus lesions.
  2. Mechanism of Injury:
    • High-energy trauma is often associated with severe lesions, such as nerve root avulsions.
  3. Diagnosis:
    • Location and Severity Assessment:
      • Differentiate between supraclavicular and infraclavicular injuries.
    • Specific Indicators of Preganglionic Lesions (Nerve Root Avulsions):
      • Horner Sign (Sympathetic Chain Involvement): Ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis.
      • Winged Scapula: Due to involvement of the long thoracic nerve affecting the serratus anterior muscle.
      • Weak Rhomboids: Due to involvement of the dorsal scapular nerve.
      • Motor Deficits with Intact Sensory Function: Indicates that cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglia are intact.
      • Electromyography (EMG): Shows loss of innervation to paraspinal muscles.
      • Elevated Hemidiaphragm: Indicates phrenic nerve involvement.
    • Radiographic Evaluation:
      • Complete imaging series including cervical spine, chest, and shoulder girdle.
      • Inspiratory and expiratory chest radiographs to detect paralyzed hemidiaphragm.
      • Transverse spinal process fractures may indicate nerve root avulsions.
      • Scapulothoracic dissociation is often linked to multiple root avulsions and major vascular injury.
    • Advanced Imaging:
      • CT Myelography: Detects nerve root avulsions.
      • MRI: Identifies peripheral neuromas, pseudomeningoceles, and mass lesions.
    • Electrodiagnostic Studies:
      • EMG: Evaluates injury extent, denervation (fibrillation potentials), and monitors recovery.
      • Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS): Assesses injury extent and monitors recovery.
      • Sensory Nerve Action Potentials (SNAPs): Normal SNAPs with loss of sensation on examination indicate preganglionic injury.
      • Somatosensory Evoked Potentials (SSEPs): Assesses nerve root continuity; performed 4–6 weeks after injury (Wallerian degeneration).

Option A - Dorsal scapular nerve arises from ventral ramus of C5 root.

Option B - Histamine test is normal (positive triple response of vasodilation, wheal formation and flare) in preganglionic injuries but in post ganglionic injuries flare is absent.

Option C - Normal SNAPs but loss of sensation on examination indicates preganglionic

Option D - MRI shows pseudomeningocele formation in preganglionic lesions.

Key takeaways:

Brachial Plexus Preganglionic Injury:

  • Normal Histamine test
  • Normal SNAP But loss of sensation.
  • Psuedomeningocele on MRI

choices.text: Policeman tip deformity in Erb's palsy
Milwaukee brace is used in brachial plexus injuries
Traction during childbirth causes Erb's palsy

questions.text: A short heighted mother underwent prolonged labour during childbirth. After a while she noticed that the child is not moving its left upper limb. Careful examination revealed the child to have got brachial plexus injury during childbirth. Select the false statement:
questions.solution:
Erb's Palsy

  • Definition: Erb's Palsy is a neurological deficit involving injury to the C5 and C6 nerve roots of the brachial plexus, affecting the upper limb.
  • Causes:
    • Most commonly caused by excessive lateral traction or stretching (Option D) of a baby's head and neck during childbirth.
    • In adults, it can result from trauma involving forceful separation of the neck from the shoulder.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Affects nerves that control the deltoid, biceps, brachialis, and brachioradialis muscles, leading to paralysis or weakness in shoulder abduction, external rotation, elbow flexion, and forearm supination.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • (Option A)"Policeman's Tip Deformity": Arm is adducted and internally rotated, elbow extended, forearm pronounced, and wrist flexed.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Based on clinical presentation, history of trauma or birth complications, and possibly imaging (X-rays, MRI).
  • Management:
    • Conservative: Physical therapy and exercises for mild cases.
    • Surgical: Nerve repair or transfer for severe cases not improving within 3-6 months.
  • Prognosis:
    • Depends on the severity; mild cases often recover fully, while severe cases may need surgical intervention.

Option A: Policeman's Tip Deformity is seen in Erb's palsy

Option B: Klumpke's palsy is injury to the lower trunk C8 and partially T1 which gives rise to claw hand deformity.

Option C: Milwaukee brace is used in scoliosis. Aeroplane splint is used for brachial plexus injury.

Option D: Traction during childbirth causes Erb's palsy is correct.

Key takeaways:

Erbs Palsy:

  • C5-C6 Deficit at Erb's Point
  • Policeman tip deformity
  • Aeroplane splint for Brachial plexus injury.

questions.text: A 55 yr hypothyroid female was advised for surgical release of carpal tunnel and decompression of the median nerve but she neglected the advice and kept on bearing the pain and opted for conservative management. After a few months she presented again with a thumb in the same plane as wrist. Identify the muscle paralyzed.
questions.solution:
Ape Thumb Deformity

  • Definition:
    • The thumb is in the same plane as the wrist, unable to oppose or move away from the palm.
  • Cause:
    • Occurs due to paralysis of the opponens pollicis muscle. (Option D)
  • Associated Nerve Injury:
    • Caused by median nerve palsy due to any reason.
  • Result:
    • Loss of thumb opposition, affecting gripping and pinching abilities.

This deformity affects hand function, resembling an "ape-like" appearance due to the alignment of the thumb with other fingers.

Option A - FPB is supplied by the median nerve but not at the level of the wrist joint. It gets involved in higher median nerve palsy

Option B and C - Interossei muscles are supplied by the ulnar nerve and gets paralysed in ulnar tunnel syndrome and not carpal tunnel syndrome.

Key takeaways

Tests for diagnosing CTS

  • Durkan test - Most sensitive clinical test
  • Phalen's test
  • Tinel sign
  • EMG-NCS

questions.text: All of these are potential sites of compression of median nerve leading to pronator syndrome except:
questions.solution:
(Option A) - Osborne ligament compresses the ulnar nerve.

Pronator Syndrome

  • Definition: Compression of the median nerve in the arm/forearm.
  • Potential Sites of Compression:
    • Supracondylar Process:
      • Anterior distal humerus.
      • Seen on lateral radiograph.
      • Present in ∼1% of the population.
    • Ligament of Struthers:
      • Courses between the supracondylar process and medial epicondyle.
    • Bicipital Aponeurosis (Lacertus Fibrosus).
    • FDS Aponeurotic Arch.
    • Between the Two Heads of the Pronator Teres Muscle.
  • Differentiation from Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS):
    • Pronator Syndrome:
      • Proximal volar forearm pain.
      • Sensory disturbances in the distribution of the palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve over the thenar region.
      • Decreased sensation over the thenar region.
    • CTS:
      • Normal sensation over the thenar eminence.
  • Provocative Tests:
    • Resisted elbow flexion with forearm supinated (Bicipital Aponeurosis).
    • Resisted forearm pronation with elbow extended (Pronator Teres).
    • Resisted long finger PIP joint flexion (FDS).
  • Nonoperative Treatment:
    • Activity modification.
    • Splints
    • NSAIDs
  • Surgical Treatment (if nonoperative management fails):
    • Release of all potential sites of compression.
    • Success rate is approximately 80% in most series.
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Often associated with medial epicondylitis.

Option B, C & D: Ligament of struthers, Lacertus Fibrosus and FDS Aponeurotic arch all compress median nerve in Pronator syndrome.

Key takeaways

Pronator syndrome - Compression of the median nerve in the arm/forearm.

Potential sites of compression (mnemonic: SLAPS)

  • Supracondylar process: Anterior distal humerus seen on lateral radiograph, in ∼1% of the population
  • Ligament of Struthers: Courses between the supracondylar process and medial epicondyle (Option D)
  • Bicipital aponeurosis (Lacertus fibrosus) (Option B)
  • FDS Aponeurotic Arch (Option C)
  • Between the two heads of Pronator teres muscle

questions.text: All of the following are potential sites of ulnar nerve entrapment leading to cubital tunnel syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Option B- Ligament of struthers compresses median nerve and not ulnar nerve.

Cubital Tunnel Syndrome

  • Prevalence: Second most common upper extremity compression neuropathy.
  • Anatomy:
    • Floor: Medial collateral ligament (MCL) and elbow joint capsule.
    • Walls: Medial epicondyle and olecranon.
    • Roof: Flexor carpi ulnaris (FCU) fascia and arcuate ligament of Osborne.
  • External Compression Sources:
    • Tumors, ganglions, osteophytes, heterotopic ossification (HO), medial epicondyle nonunion.
  • Associations:
    • Burns, cubitus valgus, medial epicondylitis, repetitive elbow stress.
  • Differential Diagnosis:
    • Thoracic outlet syndrome, cervical radiculopathy (C8–T1).
  • Symptoms:
    • Paresthesias in the ulnar 1½ digits and dorsal ulnar hand.
  • Provocative Tests:
    • Cubital tunnel compression, Tinel test, prolonged elbow hyperflexion.
  • Examination Findings:
    • Motor Weakness Signs:
      • Froment Sign: Thumb IP joint flexion during key pinch.
      • Jeanne Sign: Thumb MCP hyperextension with key pinch.
      • Wartenberg Sign: Persistent abduction/extension of small digit.
      • Masse Sign: Flattening of palmar arch and loss of ulnar hand elevation.
    • Atrophy: Interosseous and first web space.
  • Diagnostic Tests:
    • Electrodiagnostic tests with conduction velocity <50 m/sec across elbow indicate diagnosis.
  • Nonoperative Treatment:
    • Activity modification, night splints, FCU stretching, NSAIDs.
  • Surgical Options:
    • Techniques: In situ decompression, anterior transposition, medial epicondylectomy.
    • Outcomes: No significant difference between simple decompression and transposition if no ulnar nerve instability. Higher recurrence rate than carpal tunnel release.
  • Postoperative Considerations:
    • Persistent pain may be due to neuroma formation from iatrogenic injury.

Option A, C & D: Ulnar nerve is compressed by the medial head of triceps, Osborne ligaments and Arcade of Struthers.

Key takeaways

Cubital tunnel syndrome & Sites of compression (mnemonic: AO TEAM)

  • Arcade of Struthers: fascial thickening at hiatus of the medial intermuscular septum as the ulnar nerve passes from anterior to posterior compartment. Location: ≈8 cm proximal to the medial epicondyle
  • Osborne ligament
  • Medial head of Triceps
  • Anconeus Epitrochlearis: Anomalous muscle originating from medial olecranon and inserted on the medial epicondyle
  • Aponeurosis of the proximal edge of FDS or two heads of FCU
  • Medial intermuscular septum

questions.text: A 42 yr man presents with chronic median nerve palsy and an MRI report which shows complete discontinuity below the level of elbow joint. All of these muscles will be paralysed except:
questions.solution:
Median Nerve Anatomy and Course

Formation and General Course:

  • Formation: The median nerve is formed by the joining of branches from the lateral and medial cords of the brachial plexus.
  • Arm: It descends adjacent to the brachial artery.

Course in the Forearm:

  1. Entry:
    • Enters the forearm between the two heads of the pronator teres.
  2. Initial Path:
    • Passes deep to the tendinous bridge of the flexor digitorum superficialis in the proximal third of the forearm.
  3. Mid-Forearm:
    • Descends between the flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus.
  4. Pre-Wrist:
    • Approximately 5 cm above the wrist, it lies on the lateral side of the flexor digitorum superficialis.
  5. Near Wrist:
    • Becomes superficial just above the wrist, lying between the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor carpi radialis.

Course in the Hand:

  1. Entry to Palm:
    • Passes deep to the flexor retinaculum to enter the palm.
  2. Muscular Branches:
    • A short, stout muscular branch supplies the thenar eminence muscles:
      • Abductor pollicis brevis
      • Opponens pollicis
      • Flexor pollicis brevis
  3. Digital Branches:
    • Divides into 4 to 5 palmar digital branches supplying the skin of the palm.
    • Provides motor branches to the first and second lumbrical muscles.
    • Option A, B and C: FCR, FPL & FDS are supplied by the median nerve.
    • Option D - FCU is supplied by the ulnar nerve.

Key takeaways:

  • Median nerve is known as labourer's nerve as it supplies strong flexors of the forearm which are required for powerful activities.
  • Ulnar nerve is known as a musician's nerve as it supplies small intrinsic muscles of hand required for fine movements.
  • Radial nerve supplies the extensors of the wrist and hand in the forearm.

choices.text: Tibialis posterior muscle transfer is done for treatment

questions.text: A gentleman sustained a fracture of the head of fibula in a minor RTA which was treated conservatively by cast. After removal of the cast he developed foot drop. Select false statement regarding foot drop.
questions.solution:
Foot Drop

Definition:

  • The foot remains in plantar flexion due to weakness of the dorsiflexors.

Causes:

  • Common peroneal nerve palsy
    • The common peroneal nerve passes around the neck of the fibula and is sometimes injured in fractures around that region. (Option C)

Nerve Function:

  • The common peroneal nerve supplies the extensors and evertors of the foot. (Option B)
  • Paralysis of these muscles results in foot drop.

Gait:

  • High-Step Gait:
    • The patient lifts the foot high while walking to clear the ground.
    • The plantar flexors of the foot are normal.

Treatment for Long-Standing or Non-Recovering Foot Drop:

  • Transfer of tibialis posterior to the dorsum of the foot. (Option D)

Option A - Scissoring gait is seen in cerebral palsy hence false Option.

Key takeaways -

choices.text: Seen in mothers during difficult labor
Occurs while delivering babies with shoulder dystocia

questions.text: Meralgia paresthetica: Select the false statement.
questions.solution:
Meralgia Paresthetica: Overview

Definition:
Meralgia paresthetica is a condition characterized by tingling, burning, and numbness in the skin supplied by the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, which becomes entrapped in the fascia near the anterior superior iliac spine. (Option A)

Causes:

  • Compression Factors: Tight belts, excessive abdominal pannus, and prolonged hip flexion.

Medical Procedures: Sudden hyperflexion of the thigh, such as during McRobert’s procedure for shoulder dystocia during difficult labor, can injure the nerve. (Option B,C,D

Symptoms:

  • Tingling, burning, and numbness in the outer thigh.
  • Symptoms may worsen with compression or prolonged positions.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Evaluation: Based on symptoms and physical examination.
  • Imaging: MRI or CT to rule out other causes.

Treatment:

  • Conservative Measures: Release of compressive devices, postural exercises.
  • Medications: NSAIDs and analgesics for pain relief.
  • Local Treatments: Hydrocortisone injections.
  • Surgical Intervention: Considered if conservative treatments fail.

Prognosis:

  • Most cases improve with non-specific treatments and lifestyle modifications. Surgical decompression may be needed for persistent symptoms.

Option A: Meralgia paresthetica is due to compressive neuropathy of Lateral Cutaneous Nerve of thigh.

Key takeaways -

Compressive neuropathy:

  • Median nerve - carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • lateral femoral cutaneous nerve - meralgia paresthetica.
  • ulnar digital nerve - called bowler’s thumb
  • superficial radial nerve - cheralgia paresthetica.
